lines.text: You say you need a Wellington Bomber for test drops. They're worth their weight in gold. Do you really think the authorities will lend you one? What possible argument could I put forward to get you a Wellington?
Well, if you told them I designed it, do you think that might help?
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Every time one of these Lancasters fly over, my chickens lay premature eggs.
How many guns do you think there are, Trevor?
I'd say there are about ten guns - some in the field, and some in the tower.
Do you know how much water it takes the Germans to make a ton of steel?
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: I haven't the least idea.
One hundred tons. Now just look at this.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: [gestures to a map on his desk]

The whole of this great arsenal of war factories in the Ruhr depends for its water on three enormous dams. The Moehne. The Eder. And, the Sorpe. They control the level of the canals and supply a lot of hydroelectric power as well. When those are full they hold four hundred *million* tons of water. Just think of the chaos if we could break those walls down.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Cochrane...!
[gestures for him to wait]
Don't go for a minute. What do you think of Wallis' idea for bursting the Ruhr Dams?
It sounds a bit far-fetched. But, personally, I think it could be done.
I hope you're right. Anyway, I've given it my support, and I've had orders to get ready. I want you to take it on.
Right, sir. I'd like to. It'll mean taking a squadron out of the line for special training.
No. We must form a special squadron for this. And man it with experienced crews who have just finished their present thirty trips. Some of those keen youngsters won't mind doing an extra one.
Do you have anyone in mind to command the squadron?
Yes. Gibson.
[Whitworth is helping Gibson select pilots for the new squadron]
I'd go for these two Australians if I were you; Les Knight and Micky Martin. Martin knows pretty well all there is to know about low flying.
Yes, I met him when he was collecting his DFC. I know this New Zealander, Les Munro, I'd like to have him. Oh and Joe McCarthy, he's great.

[laughs]
Oh, the American. The Glorious Blonde. He used to be a Coney Island beachguard. We mustn't forget the English.
[leads Gibson to another personnel book of pilots]
Here's Bill Astell. Oh yes, David Maltby.
[skips over one pilot]
Oh, uh, he's just started another tour.

[points to a picture in the book]
And Hoppy Hopgood from my old squadron. I'd like to have Dave Shannon and Burpee from there too.
Well, we shan't be popular with the other squadron commanders if we start squeezing chaps like these from them.

[addressing the squadron at the briefing before the raid]
Well, the training's over. For obvious reasons, you've had to work without knowing your target, or even your weapon. You've to put up with a good deal from other people who think you've been having a soft time. But, tonight, you're going to have a chance to hit the enemy harder, and more destructively, than any small force has ever done before! You're going to attack the great dams of Western Germany!

[watching morse lamp signals between the two other planes in formation]
Martin's having a chat with Hopgood.
What's he saying, Hutch?
He says we're going to get screechers tomorrow night.
Sure we are. Biggest binge of all time.

[Harris arrives in the Operations Room to follow the progress of the attack. Officers in the room come to attention and salute]
Carry on.
[to Cochrane]
Well, Cocky, how's it going?
All right so far, sir. The first wave's about twenty miles from the Dutch coast. Enemy radar has probably picked them up by now

[Taerum consults his charts]
Skipper, groundspeed two-zero-three. We'll be there in one hour and ten minutes. We'll be over the Dutch coast in two minutes.

[Sees Dutch coast approaching]
There it is now. Stand by front-gunner, we're going over.
lines.character: Flying Officer F.M. Spafford, DFC, DFM

lines.text: Enemy coast ahead.
Sir, have a drink to celebrate. We've done the trick!
What trick?
Flying at 150 feet. No need for altimeters. No need for anything else.
Well, how's that?
Why, SIMPLE! A couple of spotlamps. One in the nose and the other in the belly. Trained to shine down and meet together at 150 feet below the aircraft.
All you've got to do is watch through the cockpit blister and keep the two spots plumb together on the ground, or the water, and there you are at 150 feet. Accurate to an inch!
Yeah, but that would mean carrying lights right into the attack!
Well, that's better than finishing up in the drink.
lines.character: Flight Lt. H.B. Martin, DSO, DFC, AFC

lines.text: That's wonderful! How did you think of it?
Oh genius, pure genius. We gave the idea to Farnborough and they did the rest.
Still need a bombsight that'll work at low level.
lines.character: Flight Lt. D.J. Shannon, DSO, DFC

lines.text: And when are we going to get the real bombs.
lines.character: Flight Lt. D.J.H. Maltby, DSO, DFC

lines.text:
[Takes Whitworth aside]
You know it's getting on these fellows' nerves not knowing a damn thing about anything.
I know. But the old boy's got new trials on Friday. You ought to go down again. He's pretty sure it'll work this time.
How are you getting on with the low flying?
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Ah, it's awfully hard to get accuracy. I mean to within a few feet. Especially at night, over water. Still, we'll find some way of doing it.
Yes, yes, it must be very difficult.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Bomb-aiming is another headache, sir. The ordinary bombsight isn't accurate enough at such a low level. And you want the aircraft to drop their bombs dead on the same spot, one after another?
Yes, yes, within a few feet.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Well, we'll look after our headaches and leave you to look after yours.
I'm afraid that's all we can do at present. Oh, I shall get it right within a few days. You must try and come down again.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: I'd like to, sir.

[showing Gibson a model of the targets]
Well, Gibson, there it is. That's your main target - the Moehne Dam.
So *that's* it. I thought it was going to be the "Tirpitz".
If you can blow a hole in this wall...
[points to model]
-you'll bring the Ruhr steel industry to a standstill; and do much other damage besides. I'm showing you the targets. But you'll be the only man in the squadron who knows, so keep it that way.
Very good, sir.

[indicates other models]
And these are the models of the two other dams, the Eder and the Sorpe. But, the Moehne is the most important one.
I see, sir.

Come along and study these as often as you like. We're having regular reconnaissance to see what they're doing over there and what's the height of the water. The operation must be carried out when the lakes are full.
When's that likely to be, sir?

About the middle of May. You'll need a good moon as well. So, it looks like we're tied to a night between the 12th and the 17th. By the time the next full moon comes around the water level will have started to fall again, so it's our only chance this year. About five weeks from now. How's the training going?
Oh, pretty well sir. Except for the low flying.
Yes, I guessed you'd be in trouble over that.
It's fairly easy by day, but night flying over water at 150 feet is pretty near impossible.
You can't trust your altimeters?

No to the limits Mister Wallis wants. He insists on 150 feet. Not a foot below, or a foot above. I'd hoped we could get over it by practice. But, on still nights, when the water's smooth, there's a sort of no man's land between the dusk and the water.

Well, I've got the Farnborough experts on that. I hope they'll come along with an idea. By the way, Wallis is going to test the full-sized bomb at Reculver tomorrow. I'd like you to go down and watch. Take your bombing leader with you.
Right, sir.
Good morning, Gibson.
Morning, sir.
First of all, congratulations on the bar to your DSO.
Thank you, sir.
You finished your third tour last night?
Yes sir.
Would you be prepared to take on one more trip?
What kind of trip, sir?
I can't tell you much about it, for the present. But, it'll be a special one and you'll command the operation. I'm afraid it'll mean putting off your leave. How do you feel about it?
Alright sir.

Good. It's going to need careful training, the commander-in-chief wants a special squadron formed. it'll be best if you formed it yourself. I'm telling all the squadrons they'll have to be prepared to give up some of their most experienced crews. They're not going to like it.

Well, the sixpenny bombsight works and the spotlamps work. We've flown two thousand hours, and dropped a good many more than two thousand practice bombs. The specially converted aircraft start arriving tomorrow. So, from now until the word "go" I want you to practice flying them at your all-up proper weights.
[indicates Young]
You can work that out, Dinghy. Don't forget that some of the armour's been taken out. And don't exceed 63,000 pounds or otherwise we shan't get off.
[looks around]
Any problems?
You want the front gunner to stay in his turret the whole time?
Oh yes, he'll have to deal with the flak guns.
The trouble with that is his feet.
[mimics with fingers]
They dangle in front of the bomb-aimer's face. How about fixing up some stirrups to get his feet out of the way and make him more comfortable?
That's a good plan.
Have you any idea when we're going, sir?
Probably within a week. But, keep it under your hats! You won't have to put up with being called "the armchair squadron" much longer
Two months without an operation is getting us stalejake now.
There was damn near a riot yesterday when somebody in 57 Squadron started it again
Our fellows would feel better if they blew off steam
lines.character: Flight Lt. H.B. Martin, DSO, DFC, AFC

lines.text:
[grins]
Alright, the next time somebody starts being funny, have a riot.
[assembled pilots laugh]
Alright, that's all.
[pilots get up to leave]
How'd you get on?
It's hopeless.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: What happened?
Nothing. I walked up and down Whitehall. In and out of offices. Up and down stairs. Sat outside rooms. I felt like a peddlar trying to sell clockwork toys.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: I wish there was something I could do.
There is, Mutt.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: What?
Let's take the whole thing straight to Bomber Command.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Harris?
Yes! You're one of the few men that really know him. If he sees the films and gets interested... Well, it'll only need one word from him.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: [sees Mutt shaking his head]
Why not?
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Well, there's a bit of a snag there. See, he gets so innundated with fantastic inventions...
Oh, that's ridiculous! Everything he's using had to have been invented. Look, if you tell him that it's worthwhile he'll listen to you, won't he?
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: I'll do what I can... But don't blame me if he throws us both out of the window.

[Wallis and Summers have come into his office]
Hello, Mutt. Wallis.
Good morning.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: What is it you want?
I've got an idea for destroying the Ruhr Dams. The effects on Germany would be enormous.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: I know all that. I've read the report.
[thumps file folder on his desk]
But, do you *really* think you can knock down a dam with *that* thing?
Yes.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Well, it looks clever enough on paper. But that goes for *all* of these wheezy ideas. When you try to make them work, they fall down *flat*.
This one doesn't.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: How do you know?
We've tested it and proved it. I've got some films here I'd like you to see.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text:
[mildly surprised]
Why... If you've proved the thing, why hasn't it been taken up?
I don't know. But the films only take five minutes to run. You could see them and judge for yourself.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Well... All right.
[gets up from desk and heads toward projection room]
Send the projectionist out of the room. If this thing's as good as you say, there's no point in letting everyone know.
[indicates his aide, Air Vice-Marshall Saundby]
Saundby can run the film.

[looks at message sent from the attack group]
The northern wave's run into trouble on the coast. McCarthy is going on to the Sorpe Dam by himself.
[looks at map]
Gibson's formation should be nearly at the Moehne by now.

[looks out cockpit canopy at the Moehne as the attack formation arrives, and flak starts coming up]
There it is, boys. Bit aggressive, aren't they? Someone's woken them up. What do you think about it, Bob?
lines.character: Flight Lt. H.B. Martin, DSO, DFC, AFC

lines.text: My goodness. It's... It's big, isn't it? Can we really break *that*?

[Gibson calls around to the pilots as the attack starts]
"P for Popsie", are you there?
OK, Leader.
lines.character: Flight Lt. H.B. Martin, DSO, DFC, AFC

lines.text: Hello, "M Mother" are you there?
I'm here, Leader
Here, Leader.
Here, Leader.
lines.character: Flight Lt. D.J.H. Maltby, DSO, DFC

lines.text: Here, Leader
lines.character: Flight Lt. D.J. Shannon, DSO, DFC

lines.text: Here, Leader.
Here, Leader.
Hello, all Cooler aircraft. I'm going in to attack. Stand by to come in in your order when I tell you.

[as Gibson heads in to attack]
Hello "M for Mother" stand by to take over if anything happens.
OK, Leader. Good luck!
Are you in touch with the reserve formation?
All except Burpee, sir. He hasn't answered for some time.

[morning after the raid]
This is London. The Air Ministry has just issued the following communique. In the early hours of this morning, a force of Lancasters of Bomber Command, led by Wing Commander G.P. Gibson DSO DFC, attacked with mines the dams of the Moehne and Sorpe reservoirs. These control two-thirds of the water storage capacity of the Rurh Basin. Reconaissance later established that the Moehne Dam had been breached over a length of 100 yards, and that the power station below had been swept away by the resulting floods. The Eder Dam, which controls the headwaters of the Weser and Fulda Valleys, and operates several power stations, was also attacked and reported as breached. Photographs show the river below the dam in full flood. The attacks were pressed home at extremely low level with great determination and coolness in the face of fierce resistance. Eight of the Lancasters are missing.
[Last lines]

[Morning after the raid]
Is it true? All those fellows lost?
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Only two aircraft went down in the attacks. That was Hopgood's over the Moehne and Maudsley's at the Eder. Astell got it soon after crossing the coast. And Dinghy Young was shot down over the sea, on his way home. The rest we don't know about. They've been calling them since midnight, but they haven't answered. The flak was bad. Worse than I expected.

[upset]
Fifty-six men... If I'd known it was going to be like this, I'd never have started it.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Now you mustn't think that way. If all these fellows had known from the beginning they wouldn't be coming back they would have gone for it just the same. There isn't a single one of them that would have dropped out. I knew them all. I know that's true. Look, you've had a worse night than any of us. Why don't you find the doctor and ask for one of his sleeping pills?

[Shakes head]
Aren't you going to turn in, Gibby?
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: No, I... I have to write some letters first.
[Gibson walks off into distance. Theme music. Roll credits]

[after another failed test of the full-sized bomb]
Well, it's a bad business isn't it?
Yes, I'm afraid it is.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: What are you going to do?
I think I know the trouble, I must work on it again.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Well, here we are on the 22nd of April. The deadline date for the raid the 19th of May. That's barely four weeks.
Give me a few more days. A week at most.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: If you go and change the design. the factories will never do it in time...
I shan't change the design. I must just strengthen the casing and try a new method of release.
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text: Oh well, a week from today. If it doesn't work then, we shall have to call it off. There's nothing else we can do.

[Looks at his watch at dinner, before the raid]
We've still got an hour. Let's go put our feet up for a bit before we change.
Not a bad idea. C'mon.
lines.character: Flight Lt. H.B. Martin, DSO, DFC, AFC

lines.text: You know, there's such a very thin dividing line between "inspiration" and "obsession", that sometimes it's very hard to decide *which* side we're really *on*!
lines.character: Doctor B. N. Wallis, C.B.E., F.R.S.

lines.text:
[as his aircraft nears it's bombing target]
Get ready to pull me out of the seat if I get hit!
